results.title: Boomerang
results.brief_description: Jackson Jacob (Thunalgunaldin) demonstrates and explains how a returning boomerang is made. Opens with a legend describing the origin of the boomerang.

results.title: Deserted landscape
results.brief_description: Material for this film was shot by the WEA Film Society in 1959 with the co-operation of various South Australian welfare organisations, with Ian Davidson as photographer and editor. It was subsequently made into a completed film, with commentary written by Nancy Cato, by Davidson’s company Arkaba Films in 1966. The project was supported by the Workers Educational Association of South Australia.

results.title: Luke's party
results.creator_credit: Ros Sultan, Tim Burns and AFI [au]
results.brief_description: A woman picks up a video camera to make a mock documentary about growing up as a First Nations person in South Australia. As the camera starts rolling she is continually interrupted by the demands of children, friends, telephone repair people, neighbours, salespeople and representatives of a range of government bureaucracies. This delightfully tongue-in-cheek short film makes salient points about the difficulties of maintaining personal dignity in a world of economic and emotional uncertainty. The futility of her attempt to explain “herself” on camera as the world around her descends into absurd farce satirises the pretend objectivity of most social-realist documentary. Sharp, witty and surprisingly passionate, “Luke’s Party” is an exceptional short Australian film.

results.title: The Black man and his bride
results.creator_credit: Tim Burstall, Patrick Ryan and Eltham Films
results.brief_description: By using camera movement and editing technique the film animates the series of paintings “The Black Man and his Bride”, by Arthur Boyd. Tim Burstall also wrote the original ballad sung to guitar accompaniment which runs for the duration of the film sung by Donald Ayrton.

results.title: The Moka festival
results.creator_credit: J. Campbell Dobbie and Peerless Films
results.brief_description: This film shows the Moka Festival which is held deep in the heart of New Guinea. The many tribes walk great distances carrying with them a live pig lashed to a pole. The pig represents a major feature of the Moka ceremony. Wealthy chiefs distribute their wealth to the less fortunate chiefs and pigs and shells are currency between the villages. The tribal people adorn themselves with paint and feathers and dance at the “festival of giving”. Photography by Arnold M. Maahs.

results.title: Pilkington Brothers offer: the best of both worlds
results.creator_credit: Frank Worth, Cecil Musk and British Information Services

video_links.name: Pilkington Brothers offer: the best of both worlds

results.brief_description: Two visitors from outer space visit Earth in order to investigate a material unknown on their planet - glass. They are shown the many architectural uses of glass and the many varieties which are available for use.

results.title: Service to the inland
results.creator_credit: J. Campbell Dobbie and Peerless Films
results.brief_description: A story of the inland telegraph, demonstrating the need for and efficiency of the inland communications system. Shows a message from a Northern Territory bush wireless to Dunlop Tyres translated into a narrative about developments in the outback (transportation, primary industry, the flying doctor etc.). Also includes footage of Aboriginal couriers travelling overland on foot, Aboriginal settlements, their culture, cooking, food gathering etc, in particular Emily’s Gap.

results.title: Drat
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Robert Stephenson, Ann Shenfield, Sarah Watt and Elizabeth O'Neill
results.brief_description: A bunch of lab rats one night decide to break out and escape from their cages in the laboratory. One brain damaged rat, as a result of receiving shock-treatment, initially resists the call. This claymation reveals in its close yet another fiendish experiment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Robert Stephenson, Ann Shenfield, Sarah Watt and Elizabeth O’Neill
